There is no one-size-fits-all answer to this question, as what people believe and how they connect with their heritage and environment can vary widely from person to person. However, for many modern Pagans, the rituals and ceremonies they practice are not just arbitrary superstitions, but rather meaningful practices that help them feel more connected to the world around them. 

For example, in some Pagan traditions, the use of traditional symbols and practices is believed to have a deep and profound spiritual meaning. Certain rituals may be seen as a way to connect with the divine or with elemental forces, and are seen as having a very real impact on the world. In this way, the rituals are an integral part of the practitioner's spiritual experience and can help to reinforce a feeling of connectedness and belonging to something larger than oneself.

Furthermore, many modern Pagans see these practices as a way to honor their ancestors and cultural heritage. By engaging in these rituals, they are not simply partaking in empty superstitions, but are actively preserving and celebrating an important part of their cultural history.

Ultimately, it is up to each individual to decide what practices align with their own beliefs and values. While rituals and ceremonies may not resonate with everyone, for many people they offer a deeply meaningful way to connect with their heritage, environment, and higher spiritual purpose.
